text: Which Psalm begins with 'Blessed is the man who walks not in the counsel of the wicked'?
verseText: Blessed is the man who walks not in the counsel of the wicked, nor stands in the way of sinners, nor sits in the seat of scoffers;

text: Psalm 23 famously begins with 'The LORD is my...'?
verseText: The LORD is my shepherd; I shall not want.

text: According to Psalm 19, what declares the glory of God?
verseText: The heavens declare the glory of God, and the sky above proclaims his handiwork.

text: Which Psalm is the longest chapter in the Bible?
verseText: (Reference to the entire Psalm structure)

text: Psalm 51 is a well-known psalm of repentance attributed to which king after his sin with Bathsheba?
verseText: To the choirmaster. A Psalm of David, when Nathan the prophet went to him, after he had gone in to Bathsheba.

text: What does Psalm 46:1 call God?
verseText: God is our refuge and strength, a very present help in trouble.

text: Which Psalm contains the verse 'Be still, and know that I am God'?
verseText: “Be still, and know that I am God. I will be exalted among the nations, I will be exalted in the earth!”

text: Psalm 91 speaks of God's protection. Under what does the psalmist say one can find refuge?
verseText: He who dwells in the shelter of the Most High will abide in the shadow of the Almighty... He will cover you with his pinions, and under his wings you will find refuge;

text: Psalm 100 is a call to do what?
verseText: Make a joyful noise to the LORD, all the earth! Serve the LORD with gladness! Come into his presence with singing!

text: According to Psalm 139, where can one go to flee from God's Spirit?
options: To the depths of the sea
verseText: Where shall I go from your Spirit? Or where shall I flee from your presence? If I ascend to heaven, you are there! If I make my bed in Sheol, you are there! If I take the wings of the morning and dwell in the uttermost parts of the sea, even there your hand shall lead me, and your right hand shall hold me.

text: What does the blessed man in Psalm 1 delight in?
verseText: but his delight is in the law of the LORD, and on his law he meditates day and night.

text: The blessed man in Psalm 1 is compared to what, planted by streams of water?
verseText: He is like a tree planted by streams of water that yields its fruit in its season, and its leaf does not wither. In all that he does, he prospers.

text: Psalm 2 speaks of the nations raging and plotting in vain against whom?
verseText: Why do the nations rage and the peoples plot in vain? The kings of the earth set themselves, and the rulers take counsel together, against the LORD and against his Anointed,

text: In Psalm 8, the psalmist marvels that God is mindful of whom, considering the majesty of the heavens?
verseText: When I look at your heavens, the work of your fingers, the moon and the stars, which you have set in place, what is man that you are mindful of him, and the son of man that you care for him?

text: What does Psalm 14:1 say the fool says in his heart?
verseText: The fool says in his heart, “There is no God.” They are corrupt, they do abominable deeds; there is none who does good.

text: Psalm 15 asks who may dwell in God's holy hill. What is one characteristic mentioned?
options: One who speaks truth in his heart
verseText: O LORD, who shall sojourn in your tent? Who shall dwell on your holy hill? He who walks blamelessly and does what is right and speaks truth in his heart;

text: In Psalm 16, the psalmist declares that the LORD is his chosen portion and his cup, and says 'the lines have fallen for me in...'?
verseText: The LORD is my chosen portion and my cup; you hold my lot. The lines have fallen for me in pleasant places; indeed, I have a beautiful inheritance.

text: What does the psalmist ask God to keep him as in Psalm 17?
verseText: Keep me as the apple of your eye; hide me in the shadow of your wings,

text: Psalm 18 begins with the declaration, 'I love you, O LORD, my...'?
verseText: I love you, O LORD, my strength.

text: Besides the heavens, what else does Psalm 19 praise as perfect and reviving the soul?
verseText: The law of the LORD is perfect, reviving the soul; the testimony of the LORD is sure, making wise the simple;

text: What does the psalmist ask God to cleanse him from in Psalm 19?
verseText: Who can discern his errors? Declare me innocent from hidden faults.

text: Psalm 20 is a prayer for the king before battle. What do some trust in, contrasting with the psalmist's trust in the name of the LORD?
verseText: Some trust in chariots and some in horses, but we trust in the name of the LORD our God.

text: Which Psalm contains the anguished cry, 'My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?'
verseText: My God, my God, why have you forsaken me? Why are you so far from saving me, from the words of my groaning?

text: Psalm 22 graphically describes suffering, including the piercing of what body parts?
verseText: For dogs encompass me; a company of evildoers encircles me; they have pierced my hands and feet—

text: In Psalm 23, even when walking through the valley of the shadow of death, why does the psalmist fear no evil?
verseText: Even though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil, for you are with me; your rod and your staff, they comfort me.

text: What does God prepare for the psalmist in the presence of his enemies in Psalm 23?
verseText: You prepare a table before me in the presence of my enemies; you anoint my head with oil; my cup overflows.

text: Psalm 24 declares that the earth and everything in it belongs to whom?
verseText: The earth is the LORD's and the fullness thereof, the world and those who dwell therein,

text: Who may ascend the hill of the LORD, according to Psalm 24?
options: Those with clean hands and a pure heart
verseText: Who shall ascend the hill of the LORD? And who shall stand in his holy place? He who has clean hands and a pure heart, who does not lift up his soul to what is false and does not swear deceitfully.

text: What is the primary request made throughout Psalm 25?
verseText: Make me to know your ways, O LORD; teach me your paths. Lead me in your truth and teach me... For your name's sake, O LORD, pardon my guilt, for it is great.

text: Psalm 27 begins, 'The LORD is my light and my salvation; whom shall I...?'
verseText: The LORD is my light and my salvation; whom shall I fear? The LORD is the stronghold of my life; of whom shall I be afraid?

text: What one thing does the psalmist ask from the LORD in Psalm 27?
options: To dwell in the house of the LORD forever
verseText: One thing have I asked of the LORD, that will I seek after: that I may dwell in the house of the LORD all the days of my life, to gaze upon the beauty of the LORD and to inquire in his temple.

text: Psalm 29 calls the 'heavenly beings' (or 'sons of God') to ascribe what to the LORD?
verseText: Ascribe to the LORD, O heavenly beings, ascribe to the LORD glory and strength.

text: The voice of the LORD in Psalm 29 is described as powerful and majestic, having power over what natural element?
verseText: The voice of the LORD is over the waters; the God of glory thunders, the LORD, over many waters.

text: In Psalm 32, what is the state of the person whose transgression is forgiven and whose sin is covered?
verseText: Blessed is the one whose transgression is forgiven, whose sin is covered.

text: What happens when the psalmist keeps silent about his sin, according to Psalm 32?
verseText: For when I kept silent, my bones wasted away through my groaning all day long.

text: Psalm 34 contains the invitation, 'Oh, taste and see that the LORD is...'?
verseText: Oh, taste and see that the LORD is good! Blessed is the man who takes refuge in him!

text: According to Psalm 34, the righteous face many afflictions, but what does the LORD do?
options: He delivers them out of them all
verseText: Many are the afflictions of the righteous, but the LORD delivers him out of them all.

text: What does Psalm 37 advise against doing when wicked people succeed?
verseText: Fret not yourself because of evildoers; be not envious of wrongdoers!

text: What are the righteous encouraged to do in Psalm 37, with the promise that God will give them the desires of their heart?
options: Trust in the LORD and do good
verseText: Trust in the LORD, and do good; dwell in the land and befriend faithfulness. Delight yourself in the LORD, and he will give you the desires of your heart.

text: Psalm 39 is a meditation on the brevity and frailty of what?
verseText: “O LORD, make me know my end and what is the measure of my days; let me know how fleeting I am! Behold, you have made my days a few handbreadths, and my lifetime is as nothing before you.

text: In Psalm 40, the psalmist speaks of waiting patiently for the LORD and being lifted out of what?
verseText: I waited patiently for the LORD; he inclined to me and heard my cry. He drew me up from the pit of destruction, out of the miry bog, and set my feet upon a rock, making my steps secure.

text: What does the psalmist desire more than sacrifice and offering, according to Psalm 40?
verseText: In sacrifice and offering you have not delighted, but you have given me an open ear. Burnt offering and sin offering you have not required.

text: Psalm 42 expresses a deep longing for God, comparing the soul's thirst to what animal panting for water?
verseText: As a deer pants for flowing streams, so pants my soul for you, O God.

text: What question does the psalmist repeatedly ask his soul in Psalms 42 and 43 when feeling downcast?
options: 'Why are you cast down, O my soul?'
verseText: Why are you cast down, O my soul, and why are you in turmoil within me? Hope in God; for I shall again praise him, my salvation and my God.

text: Psalm 51 contains the plea, 'Create in me a clean..., O God.'
verseText: Create in me a clean heart, O God, and renew a right spirit within me.

text: What kind of sacrifice does Psalm 51 say God desires, rather than burnt offerings?
options: A broken spirit; a broken and contrite heart
verseText: For you will not delight in sacrifice, or I would give it; you will not be pleased with a burnt offering. The sacrifices of God are a broken spirit; a broken and contrite heart, O God, you will not despise.

text: Psalm 62 emphasizes trusting in God alone. What are people compared to, suggesting their unreliability?
options: A mere breath, lighter than a breath
verseText: Those of low estate are but a breath; those of high estate are a delusion; in the balances they go up; they are together lighter than a breath.

text: Psalm 63 expresses deep longing for God, often associated with being in what kind of environment?
verseText: A Psalm of David, when he was in the wilderness of Judah. O God, you are my God; earnestly I seek you; my soul thirsts for you; my flesh faints for you, as in a dry and weary land where there is no water.

text: Psalm 73 describes the psalmist's struggle with seeing the prosperity of whom?
verseText: But as for me, my feet had almost stumbled, my steps had nearly slipped. For I was envious of the arrogant when I saw the prosperity of the wicked.

text: What changed the psalmist's perspective on the prosperity of the wicked in Psalm 73?
options: He went into the sanctuary of God
verseText: But when I thought how to understand this, it seemed to me a wearisome task, until I went into the sanctuary of God; then I discerned their end.

text: Psalm 84 expresses a deep love for God's dwelling place. How lovely is God's dwelling place, according to the psalmist?
options: How lovely is your dwelling place!
verseText: How lovely is your dwelling place, O LORD of hosts!

text: What would the psalmist rather be in the house of God than dwell in the tents of wickedness, according to Psalm 84?
verseText: For a day in your courts is better than a thousand elsewhere. I would rather be a doorkeeper in the house of my God than dwell in the tents of wickedness.

text: Psalm 90, attributed to Moses, is a meditation on God's eternality compared to human...?
verseText: Lord, you have been our dwelling place in all generations. Before the mountains were brought forth... you are God. You return man to dust... For a thousand years in your sight are but as yesterday...

text: What does Psalm 90 ask God to teach us to do, in light of life's brevity?
verseText: So teach us to number our days that we may get a heart of wisdom.

text: Psalm 91 promises deliverance from the 'deadly pestilence' and what hidden danger?
verseText: For he will deliver you from the snare of the fowler and from the deadly pestilence.

text: What will God command concerning the one who dwells in His shelter, according to Psalm 91?
options: The sun to shine on them
The earth to yield fruit for them
verseText: For he will command his angels concerning you to guard you in all your ways.

text: Psalm 95 begins with a call to sing and make a joyful noise to whom?
verseText: Oh come, let us sing to the LORD; let us make a joyful noise to the rock of our salvation!

text: Psalm 95 warns against hardening one's heart, referencing what event in Israel's history?
options: The crossing of the Red Sea
The giving of the Law at Sinai
The rebellion at Meribah and Massah
verseText: Do not harden your hearts, as at Meribah, as on the day at Massah in the wilderness, when your fathers put me to the test and put me to the proof, though they had seen my work.

text: Psalm 103 calls upon what part of the psalmist's being to bless the LORD?
verseText: Bless the LORD, O my soul, and all that is within me, bless his holy name!

text: What benefits does Psalm 103 list, including forgiveness and healing?
options: Forgives all your iniquity, heals all your diseases
Gives you wealth, grants you power
Makes you famous, gives you long life
Defeats your enemies, establishes your throne
verseText: Bless the LORD, O my soul, and forget not all his benefits, who forgives all your iniquity, who heals all your diseases,

text: How far does Psalm 103 say God removes our transgressions from us?
options: As far as the north is from the south
As far as the east is from the west
As far as the heavens are from the earth
As far as the sea is from the land
verseText: as far as the east is from the west, so far does he remove our transgressions from us.

text: Psalm 104 is a majestic hymn celebrating God as what?
verseText: (Psalm celebrating God's creation and sustenance of the world)

text: Psalm 107 recounts God's deliverance for various groups in distress. Which group is NOT explicitly mentioned?
verseText: (Recounts deliverance for wanderers, prisoners, fools/sick, and seafarers)

text: What refrain is repeated in Psalm 107, calling people to thank the LORD?
options: 'Let them thank the LORD for his steadfast love'
verseText: Let them thank the LORD for his steadfast love, for his wondrous works to the children of man!

text: Psalm 110 speaks of a priestly king. After whose order is this king a priest forever?
verseText: The LORD has sworn and will not change his mind, “You are a priest forever after the order of Melchizedek.”

text: According to Psalm 111, what is the beginning of wisdom?
verseText: The fear of the LORD is the beginning of wisdom; all those who practice it have a good understanding. His praise endures forever!

text: Psalm 118 contains the line, 'The stone that the builders rejected has become the...'?
verseText: The stone that the builders rejected has become the cornerstone.

text: What phrase is repeated in every verse of Psalm 136?
verseText: (Refrain repeated throughout the Psalm)

text: Psalm 119 is an extended meditation on the excellence of what?
verseText: (Psalm focused entirely on God's Word)

text: How does the psalmist describe God's word in relation to his path in Psalm 119?
options: A lamp to my feet and a light to my path
verseText: Your word is a lamp to my feet and a light to my path.

text: What has the psalmist stored up in his heart, according to Psalm 119, to avoid sinning against God?
verseText: I have stored up your word in my heart, that I might not sin against you.

text: Psalm 121 begins, 'I lift up my eyes to the hills. From where does my help come?' What is the answer?
options: My help comes from the LORD
verseText: I lift up my eyes to the hills. From where does my help come? My help comes from the LORD, who made heaven and earth.

text: What assurance is given in Psalm 121 regarding the Keeper of Israel?
options: He will neither slumber nor sleep
verseText: Behold, he who keeps Israel will neither slumber nor sleep.

text: Psalm 127 states that unless the LORD builds the house, what happens?
options: Those who build it labor in vain
verseText: Unless the LORD builds the house, those who build it labor in vain. Unless the LORD watches over the city, the watchman stays awake in vain.

text: What are described as a heritage from the LORD and a reward in Psalm 127?
verseText: Behold, children are a heritage from the LORD, the fruit of the womb a reward.

text: Psalm 130 is a cry to God from where?
verseText: Out of the depths I cry to you, O LORD!

text: What does the psalmist wait for more than watchmen wait for the morning, according to Psalm 130?
verseText: I wait for the LORD, my soul waits, and in his word I hope; my soul waits for the Lord more than watchmen for the morning, more than watchmen for the morning.

text: Psalm 133 celebrates the goodness and pleasantness of what?
verseText: Behold, how good and pleasant it is when brothers dwell in unity!

text: Psalm 137 expresses the sorrow of the exiles. By which rivers did they sit down and weep?
verseText: By the waters of Babylon, there we sat down and wept, when we remembered Zion.

text: What do the exiles in Psalm 137 say should happen if they forget Jerusalem?
options: May their right hand forget its skill
verseText: If I forget you, O Jerusalem, let my right hand forget its skill!

text: According to Psalm 139, when did God know the psalmist?
options: When he was being made in the womb
verseText: For you formed my inward parts; you knitted me together in my mother's womb... Your eyes saw my unformed substance; in your book were written, every one of them, the days that were formed for me, when as yet there was none of them.

text: How does the psalmist describe his formation in the womb in Psalm 139?
verseText: I praise you, for I am fearfully and wonderfully made. Wonderful are your works; my soul knows it very well.

text: Psalm 145 is described in its superscription as a psalm of what?
verseText: A Song of Praise. Of David.

text: Psalm 150, the final psalm, calls for praise using what?
verseText: Praise him with trumpet sound; praise him with lute and harp! Praise him with tambourine and dance; praise him with strings and pipe! Praise him with sounding cymbals; praise him with loud clashing cymbals!

text: How does Psalm 150 conclude the entire book of Psalms?
options: Let everything that has breath praise the LORD!
verseText: Let everything that has breath praise the LORD! Praise the LORD!
